course.subject: CIVL
course.name: Environmental Assessment and Management
course.description: Present current environmental issues and management concepts; apply essential chemical and physical principles required to understand pollution problems; integrate knowledge from science and engineering to solve and assess environmental problems affecting water, air, noise and waste; cover concepts, ordinances and case studies of environmental impact assessment of civil infrastructure projects.
course.prerequisites: (CHEM 1010 OR CHEM 1020) AND CIVL 1100

reviews.author: Mango Pudding
reviews.title: Midterm determines your grade
reviews.comment_content:
= Basics & Water (Prof. Shang) =
▷ Intro to environmental engineering, sustainable development, and EIA
▷ Units & Mass balance
▷ Environmental chemistry
▷ Environmental risk
▷ Solid waste management
▷ Water resources and pollution
▷ Water quality modelling
▷ Water supply and treatment
▷ Wastewater treatment
= Air (Prof. Song) =
▷ Air quality and pollution
▷ Air pollution modelling
▷ Air pollution control
=== Midterm content ends here ===
= Noise (Prof. Yin) =
▷ Noise pollution and control
= EIA (Prof. Yin) =
▷ Going through different parts of an EIA report

They keep improving and changing the course, so it might be different for different semesters.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Shang is the most engaging one out of the three and uses Mentimeter for in-class exercises and real-time responses from students (so that we don't have to speak up, nice gesture).

The other professors are a bit boring, just following the slides, nothing notable. Though for the EIA report, Prof. Yin sometimes gives hints on which parts are more important and what potential additional content may impress the TAs to have a greater chance of scoring higher. (To be honest, the midterm is way more important anyway.)
reviews.comment_grading:
▷ Midterm 60% (Closed-book w/ a HANDWRITTEN cheat sheet, one-sided A4 OR double-sided A5)
▷ EIA Report 20% (Due shortly after final exam period)
▷ Homework 20% (5 total, 4% each)

Midterm is a rush, MC on concepts & simple calculation + long questions similar to homework. They told us the topic coverage of the questions via a Canvas announcement.

Prof. Yin said that the midterm pretty much settled the grade and did not intend to use the EIA report to influence it. Since the score for the report is hidden, I assume that as long as the report is reasonable, everyone would have about the same score.
reviews.comment_workload:
5 simple homework during the semester, easily solved with lecture content and examples (more examples in tutorials, slides are available on Canvas anyway). "A" workload rating during the semester.

1600-2000 word individual EIA report after final exams, this semester is on TKO Desalination Plant, and essentially is a replica of the real report but with non-noise-related parts excluded. "C" to even "D" workload rating for this. You may think: "That's even more than LANG", but then you'll quickly find out that it isn't even enough after reading different EIA reports (a trick is to convert bullet points into tables since tables do not count towards the word count). Personally, it took me 4 days to complete including reading 6 other EIA reports to see how professionals write them. It was so sad seeing friends travelling already while you were still alone working on the report.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Don't expect good teaching from professors who have a strong accent.
I email them instead and I appreciate their attitude as they are willing and helpful in answering our questions (although they may not give us the direction and due to grading reasons)

Trust me, you need to email prof Li when writing EIA report alone, or you will be so miserable
reviews.comment_grading:
This year grading scheme is a bit different from previous semester.
I would say that it has both pros and cons, it is good that assignment ratio is pushed up (they are super easy indeed) but writing an individual EIA is a total hell.

20% assignment (me:14/14, mean 11.9/14, 5 assignments in total with unequal ratios)
50% online exam (includes both MCQs and LQs, 25% each)
(For MCQ (closed book), me 16/35, mean 16.87/35)
(For LQ (open book), me 15/30, mean 13.03/30)

30% individual EIA report on Disneyland construction (either water, noise or air is assigned), (mean 23.1/30, SD: 5.7/30)

Final grade: B+
I think I might have done a pretty good job in the EIA (the professor didn't release the grade of EIA report)

Grading quite fits my expectation
reviews.comment_workload:
Part 1: You only need to do easy homework and prepare for the exam, which is so demanding (35 MCQs in 50 mins and 3 LQ in 45 mins), the questions are not quite strictly forward, no wonder why the mean is so low. Practices are needed!

Part 2: I don't know why the professor need us to write an individual EIA report alone and set up a lot of guidelines in writing it ( you need to squeeze the original around 4000-5000 word EIA and rephrase them into a 2000 word one, it takes a lot of time (approx 5-6 times of a LANG2030 essay), but I think it is worth in terms of outcome

reviews.author: chpoonag
reviews.comment_content:
In this year, the course was restructured.

This course was divided into 2 parts: one before the midterm exam, one after.

1st part:
Lectures should be similar to those taught in the previous year's. The midterm exam covered all contents taught in the lectures.

2nd part:
This was the part different from the previous years'. In this part, you will have to work with your sub-groupmates to finish 1 section of an EIA report about a modified real construction case. Weekly groupwork was assigned. Those work formed the section to be submitted at the end of the final exam period (to form a complete EIA report with other sub-groups, but actually we just handed in our own section in the end)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof SHANG just skipped all iPRS sections and said they were too easy to be discussed. It was obvious that the content of this course should not be too deep due to time constraint. He did not explained anything too deeply, especially how some formulae came out.

Dr LI was a patient, passionate and responsive teacher responsible for the 2nd part of the lecture. I always have questions and he was willing to answer all.
reviews.comment_grading:
EIA report (group/subgroup): 20%
Subgroup video presentation (subgroup): 5%
Mini-quiz (individual): 5%
Homework (subgroup/individual): 5%
Classroom discussion, contribution, leadership (individual): 10%
Peer evaluation in group (subgroup): 5%
Peer evaluation in subgroup (individual): 5%

Some statistics:
Exam: mean 64.71, sd 16.19, high 99, low 16.5
EIA report: 20/20
Subgroup video presentation: 5/5
Mini-quiz: 4.83/5
Homework: 5.00/5
Discussion: 10.00/10
Peer evaluation in group: 5/5
Peer evaluation in subgroup: 5/5
Grade: A+

In my original point of view, the course grade should be mainly reliant on the midterm exam as it was predicted that the score of each group's EIA report should be more or less the same. However, the fact is that I got 94/100 in the midterm exam and my sub-groupmate got 80 and both of us got A+. Grading of this course is very good. It seems that the percentage of A+ is higher than that of grade A within the A range.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite low, especially after the midterm exam.
The only busy time would be the period before the midterm exam as you may want to recite the materials, or maybe the period for preparing the video presentation. No cheat sheet was allowed.

Note that our group did not really participate in the video presentation. We just made use of online script reader. The course outline did not specifically require us to present in person. Also, the TA will just refer to your slides.

1. To introduce students to fundamental physical and chemical principles governing the fate and transport
of pollutants in the environment, and their effects on environmental quality.

2. To expose students to real world problems affecting water, air and land resources.

3. To provide students with an understanding of engineering management solutions to environmental
problems.

4. To provide students with an understanding of basic concepts of environmental impact assessment and
related regulations.
reviews.comment_grading:
Students’ grades are determined according to the following distribution: midterm examination (30%), final
examination (50%), best of midterm and final examinations (12%), in-class exercises (8%).

Class attendance
Class attendance is not compulsory and is not tracked. Nonetheless, students are strongly encouraged to attend
all lectures. Any material covered or announcement made during a student’s absence will not be repeated.
reviews.comment_workload:
There is no homework. However, there are weekly tutorials conducted by the teaching assistants where preassigned
practice questions are discussed. The tutorials also serve as open question-and-answer sessions where
students may raise questions concerning the topic of the week.


In-class exercises are small exercises carried out during lecture to facilitate student learning, and reward class
attendance and attentiveness. They are in the form of multiple choice questions that are to be answered using
the Personal Response System (PRS). The answers are automatically graded by the system and feedback is
instantaneous. When answering the questions, students may discuss with neighbors. The exercises account for
8% of the final grade, and will be based on 45% of the best of all the exercises.

Personal Response System (PRS)
Using PRS, students are to answer questions posed in class using dedicated handsets or the PRS app via a
smartphone.

reviews.comment_teaching: Dr. Ling adopts a blended style of learning for his lectures, basically we have to study the slides before the class and we use the class time to test our knowledge and ask questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework assignments (20%):
- 5 homework assignments
- Calculations in the homework can be reused for the EIA report.

Midterm exam (50%):
- Part 1 of the exam consist 35 MCQs, 50 minutes, closed-book, backtracking is allowed.
- Part 2 of the exam consist of 3 long calculation questions, 45 minutes, open-book.

EIA report (30%):
- 1600-2000 words
- Assessment of air/water/noise impact.
- 10% mark deduction of total mark per day.

Comments: The mean for homework assignments and the EIA report is high, hence the midterm exams are the deciding factor.
reviews.comment_workload:
- Homework is not really tough, calculations can be reused for the EIA report.
- EIA report is time consuming even though you are basically summarizing. It is very easy to lose track of your word count limit and  overwrite, the word cutting process is the hardest part for me. But I would say it's still manageable overall since there's no final exam.
